title: The end of one-size-fits-all: Obesity diagnosis enters a new era - Hindustan Times
summary:
Obesity Diagnosis Evolves Beyond BMI Standards

Date: January 18, 2025

Source: Hindustan Times

A new report from the Lancet Global Commission calls for moving beyond Body Mass Index (BMI) to diagnose obesity more accurately by incorporating additional health metrics.

  • The report advocates for using waist circumference and waist-to-hip ratio as key indicators.
  • BMI has been criticized for not considering muscle mass and other health factors.
  • Medical experts emphasize the importance of assessing visceral fat due to its health risks.
  • The study is backed by over 75 medical organizations, including the AIAARO.
  • Advanced imaging techniques like CT scans could provide deeper insights into body fat assessment.
“BMI has long been used as a simple measure, but it doesn’t tell the whole story of an individual’s health.” - Dr. RR Dutta

This shift in obesity diagnosis may lead to more personalized healthcare approaches and improved health outcomes for individuals.
newTitle: Obesity Diagnosis Evolves Beyond BMI Standards

Delhi hospital performs rare kidney auto-transplant on 6-year-old Uzbek child with bilateral Wilms tumour - The Times of India
summary:
Delhi Hospital Performs Rare Kidney Auto-Transplant on 6-Year-Old Uzbek Child with Bilateral Wilms Tumour

Publication Date: Latest Update | Source: Times of India

This groundbreaking procedure highlights the advancements in pediatric surgical care, as surgeons successfully perform a rare kidney auto-transplant on a young child suffering from bilateral Wilms tumour.

  • The child, aged 6, underwent the surgery due to complications from the cancer.
  • The auto-transplant involved removing the affected kidney and placing the healthy one in a different location.
  • Surgeons reported successful outcomes and the child is recovering well.
  • This procedure is noted for its complexity and rarity, especially in young pediatric patients.
“We are hopeful for a full recovery, and the surgery marks a significant achievement in pediatric oncology,” said the lead surgeon.

This procedure not only provides hope for the young patient but also sets a precedent for future surgical interventions in similar cases.
newTitle: Delhi Hospital Performs Kidney Auto-Transplant on Young Patient with Wilms Tumour

title: Cancer cases increasing among young adults, simple lifestyle changes to reduce the risk - India TV News
summary:
Cancer cases increasing among young adults, simple lifestyle changes to reduce the risk

Publication Date: January 2025

Source: American Cancer Society

Cancer cases among young adults, particularly women, are rising alarmingly, according to a recent report by the American Cancer Society, highlighting early onset cancers.

  • Increases in early onset cancers including breast, colorectal, pancreatic, and uterine cancers among adults under 50.
  • Several lifestyle choices can help reduce cancer risk.
  • Key recommendations include not using tobacco, eating healthy foods, moderating alcohol intake, maintaining a healthy weight through physical activity, and protecting against sun exposure.
Experts note that while cancer cannot be entirely avoided, certain lifestyle choices can significantly lower the risk.

In conclusion, awareness and proactive lifestyle changes are vital in combating the rising cancer cases among young adults.
newTitle: Growing Concerns About Rising Cancer Cases Among Young Adults

Gene therapy exempted from GST; duty cuts on critical medicines for cancer and rare diseases expected - The Financial Express
summary:
Gene Therapy Exempted from GST; Duty Cuts on Critical Medicines for Cancer and Rare Diseases Expected

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Financial Express

The Central Board of Indirect Taxes and Customs (CBIC) has announced a full exemption of Goods and Service Tax (GST) on gene therapy, which is crucial for treating life-threatening diseases. This exemption is effective immediately.

  • The GST on gene therapy was previously set at 12%.
  • Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman had announced this exemption last month.
  • The move is expected to significantly impact patients requiring life-saving treatments.
  • Future proposals may include duty cuts for medicines treating cancer and rare diseases in the Union budget 2025.
  • The National Policy for Rare Diseases (NPRD) was introduced to manage various rare diseases comprehensively.
“An New Entry 105A has been inserted in Notification No. 02/2017-Central Tax (Rate) to fully exempt Gene Therapy from GST,” CBIC stated.

This exemption is anticipated to make critical therapies more affordable, alleviating the financial burden on patients.
newTitle: Gene Therapy Exempted from GST; Duty Cuts on Critical Medicines for Cancer and Rare Diseases Expected

title: Study decodes why sickle cell patients suffer cognitive problems - The Hans India
summary:
Study Decodes Why Sickle Cell Patients Suffer Cognitive Problems

Publication Date: Not specified Source: JAMA Network Open

An ageing brain in people with sickle cell disease may be responsible for cognitive problems, according to a study conducted by researchers at Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis.

  • Sickle cell disease is a genetic blood disorder characterized by abnormal hemoglobin.
  • Patients experience cognitive issues like trouble with memory, focus, and learning, even without brain stroke.
  • The study involved over 200 young adults undergoing brain MRI scans and cognitive tests.
  • Results showed participants with sickle cell disease had brains that appeared an average of 14 years older than their actual age.
  • Participants experiencing economic deprivation also showed older-looking brains, with a seven-year gap found in healthy individuals.
  • Professor Andria Ford emphasized the chronic lack of oxygen due to sickle cell disease affects brain growth from birth.
  • The findings highlight the need for understanding how sickle cell disease and economic factors influence brain structure and cognitive function.
“Sickle cell disease is congenital, chronically depriving the developing brain of oxygen and possibly affecting its growth from birth.” – Andria Ford, Professor of Neurology

This study suggests a need for further research into potential treatments and preventive measures to help preserve cognitive function in those affected by sickle cell disease and economic hardships.
newTitle: Study Finds Link Between Sickle Cell Disease and Cognitive Decline

title: 8 best before-meal workouts to reduce belly fat naturally - The Times of India
AI-driven technique analyses heart cells' inner electrical signals from outside: Study - ETHealthWorld
summary:
AI-Driven Technique Analyzes Heart Cells' Inner Electrical Signals from Outside: Study

Published On: January 18, 2025 Source: ANI

A groundbreaking noninvasive approach has been developed by researchers from the University of California, San Diego, and Stanford University to monitor electrical activity inside heart muscle cells, without penetrating them. This method captures electrical signals from the cell's exterior and reconstructs them using artificial intelligence.

  • Researchers utilized nanoscale electrodes for high-precision signal reconstruction.
  • The method overcomes the limitations of invasive procedures that can damage the cells.
  • It allows a deeper understanding of cardiac function and drug responses.
  • The study has implications for safer, more effective drug screening directly on human cells.
  • The technology may be expanded to include other cell types, such as neurons.
"This could dramatically reduce the time and cost of drug development," said Zeinab Jahed.

This innovative technique promises significant advancements in personalized medicine and could reshape drug testing protocols by providing a more accurate assessment of how new drugs affect human heart cells directly.
newTitle: AI-Driven Technique Analyzes Heart Cells' Electrical Signals Noninvasively

Health News Live January 18, 2025 : Olive oil is healthy, but turns out olive leaf extract may be good too: Know its many heart health, wellness benefits - Hindustan Times
Olive oil is healthy, but turns out olive leaf extract may be good too: Know its many heart health, wellness benefits - Hindustan Times
summary:
Health Benefits of Olive Leaf Extract: A Natural Boost for Heart Wellness

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Hindustan Times

The article discusses the growing evidence regarding the health benefits of olive leaves and their extract, especially in relation to heart health. Traditionally used in the Mediterranean, olive leaves are rich in antioxidants that may contribute to reducing risks associated with heart disease.

  • Olive leaves contain oleuropein, a potent antioxidant.
  • Studies suggest that olive leaf extract may improve blood lipids and lower blood pressure.
  • Daily doses of olive leaf extract range from 250mg to 5g.
  • Inconsistencies in research results highlight the need for further studies.
  • Olive leaves can be consumed in various forms, including tea and baked goods.
“Olive leaf extract may help reduce blood pressure, improve blood lipids and help our bodies handle glucose.”

In conclusion, while olive leaf extract can provide potential health benefits, it is essential to consult with a healthcare provider, especially for individuals with existing health conditions.
newTitle: Health Benefits of Olive Leaf Extract: A Natural Boost for Heart Wellness

title: Can a blood test detect endometriosis early? Why a new study holds out hope - The Indian Express
summary:
Can a blood test detect endometriosis early? Why a new study holds out hope

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Indian Express

Australian researchers have developed a novel blood test that can detect endometriosis in its early stages. This non-invasive approach aims to reduce long diagnosis times and costly procedures.

  • The study identified 10 protein biomarkers in blood.
  • Endometriosis is a significant issue among Indian women, leading to infertility and chronic pain.
  • The blood test could encourage diagnosis in conservative communities where invasive procedures face resistance.
  • Around 25-30% of Indian women of reproductive age may be affected by endometriosis.
  • The late diagnosis can result in severe health consequences and a long delay in treatment.
“Such a test, once approved for use, can also help with detection in places where advanced medical facilities are scarce.” - Dr. Neelam Suri

The findings from this research could transform diagnostic approaches, offering hope for better management of endometriosis.
newTitle: Can a blood test detect endometriosis early? Why a new study holds out hope

title: Researchers uncover critical mutations in H5N1 bird flu strain from infected Texan - Down To Earth Magazine
summary:
Critical Mutations Found in H5N1 Bird Flu Strain from Texas

Published on: 18 Jan 2025, 6:53 am

A recent study has discovered unique mutations in an H5N1 avian influenza strain isolated from a human patient in Texas, raising concerns about the virus's potential to evolve and spread among humans.

  • Researchers identified nine mutations in the H5N1 strain from a Texas patient that are absent in strains found in cattle.
  • This strain, designated H5N1 HPhTX, demonstrates enhanced replication in human cells and increased disease severity in mice.
  • Since early 2024, the H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b has impacted approximately 928 dairy herds, infected 67 humans, and caused mass bird fatalities.
  • The human case in Texas was linked to contact with infected milk.
  • There are concerns that the virus could evolve to transmit between humans, with a previous study indicating it’s close to being transmissible.
  • US antiviral treatments remain effective against both the human and bovine strains of the virus.
“The clock is ticking for the virus to evolve to more easily infect and potentially transmit from human to human, which would be a concern.” - Professor Luis Martinez-Sobrido

In conclusion, continued monitoring of H5N1 strains and efforts to eradicate the virus in cattle populations are essential to mitigate public health risks caused by this evolving threat.
newTitle: Critical Mutations Found in H5N1 Bird Flu Strain from Texas

5 Roles of Gut Health in Overall Wellness - Mint
summary:
5 Roles of Gut Health in Overall Wellness

Publication Date: January 18, 2025
Source: Mint

The article discusses the importance of gut health and its various roles in overall wellness. It highlights how a healthy gut microbiome can influence immune systems, weight management, heart health, and blood sugar levels.

  • Regulates the immune system by interacting with immune cells.
  • Affects weight through gut dysbiosis and probiotics.
  • Supports gut health by aiding digestion and preventing harmful bacteria.
  • Impacts heart health by producing artery-blocking compounds.
  • Controls blood sugar levels, influencing diabetes risk.
"Your body is full of trillions of microbiomes living in your intestine and skin. Some are associated with disease, while some gut microbiomes are crucial for optimal health."

In conclusion, maintaining gut health is essential for overall health and wellbeing, influencing various bodily functions and potentially reducing health risks.
newTitle: 5 Roles of Gut Health in Overall Wellness

5 warning signs that you have iron deficiency - India.com
summary:
5 Warning Signs of Iron Deficiency

Publication Date: January 18, 2025 | Source: India.com

Iron deficiency is a common condition that manifests through various warning signs which can indicate low levels of iron in the body.

  • Extreme fatigue: Lack of oxygen and blood flow can lead to persistent tiredness and fatigue.
  • Pale skin: A decrease in red blood cells and hemoglobin can result in a paler skin appearance.
  • Headaches: Hormonal changes can trigger headaches, often seen in women.
  • Brittle nails: Cracking and chipping nails can be a signal of iron deficiency.
  • Cold hands: Poor blood flow often leaves hands and feet feeling cold.
This is generic information and no substitute for medical advice. Always get checked by a doctor and do not self-diagnose.

Monitoring these symptoms is essential for early detection and prevention of iron deficiency anemia.

title: Molecular epidemiology of extended-spectrum beta-lactamases and carbapenemases-producing Shigella in Africa: a systematic review and meta-analysis - BMC Infectious Diseases
summary:
Molecular Epidemiology of Extended-Spectrum Beta-Lactamases and Carbapenemases-Producing Shigella in Africa: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

Published: 18 January 2025 | Source: BMC Infectious Diseases

This systematic review investigates the molecular epidemiology of the extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBL) and carbapenemases-producing Shigella in Africa, highlighting the significant public health challenge posed by these drug-resistant strains.

  • Only 18 out of 583 articles were included in the meta-analysis.
  • Overall prevalence of ESBL and CR-producing Shigella was 41.2%.
  • Shigella flexneri was the most prevalent species at 34.5%.
  • The most common resistance genes found were blaTEM, blaOXA−1, and blaCTX−M.
  • The prevalence of carbapenemases was low (<1%).
This study highlighted Shigella flexneri as the most prevalent ESBL and CR-producing Shigella species found in various African countries. The findings indicate that ESBL and CR-producing Shigella pose a significant public health threat in Africa.

Currently, monitoring and managing multidrug-resistant Shigella infections is urgent to improve public health outcomes.
newTitle: Molecular Epidemiology of Drug-Resistant Shigella in Africa: A Systematic Review

title: Ayurveda can be new hope for Alzheimer’s Disease: Study - The Sentinel Assam
summary:
Ayurveda can be new hope for Alzheimer’s Disease: Study

Publication Date & Source: New Delhi, IANS

The study conducted by scientists at the Bose Institute in Kolkata reveals Ayurveda's potential in providing new hope for Alzheimer’s Disease through innovative methods.

  • The research team, led by Professor Anirban Bhunia, focused on combating amyloid proteins related to Alzheimer’s Disease.
  • Two strategies were employed: chemically synthesized peptides and repurposing the Ayurvedic drug Lasunadya Ghrita (LG).
  • LG demonstrated a greater efficacy in disrupting amyloid aggregation compared to chemically designed peptides.
  • The findings suggest that Ayurveda could offer solutions to complex neurodegenerative disorders.
“The water extract of these compounds, referred to as LGWE, not only disrupted the fibrillation process...but also inhibited the formation of oligomers,” said the researchers.
newTitle: Ayurveda can be new hope for Alzheimer’s Disease: Study

title: Rise in disease outbreaks alarms Africa CDC; cholera tops list of killers - Daijiworld.com
US providing Moderna $590 mn to speed mRNA pandemic for bird flu which experts fear may start a pandemic - The Economic Times
summary:
US providing Moderna $590 mn to speed mRNA pandemic for bird flu which experts fear may start a pandemic

Publication Date: Jan 18, 2025, Source: AFP

US health officials announced funding to advance the development of mRNA vaccines targeting the H5N1 bird flu virus, as fears grow of a potential pandemic. The initiative aims to enhance preparedness against emerging infectious diseases.

  • The US is awarding $590 million to Moderna for mRNA vaccine development.
  • This funding builds upon a previous $176 million awarded in July 2024.
  • Health officials express concern over the potential mutation of H5N1 into a more contagious form.
  • Since the outbreak began, 67 infections have been reported in the US, with the first death recorded recently.
“That is why this response has been a top priority for the Biden-Harris Administration and HHS,” said HHS Secretary Xavier Becerra.

The funding comes as global health officials remain vigilant about the emergence of bird flu variants that could pose significant threats to human health.
newTitle: US Funds Moderna $590 Million to Develop Bird Flu mRNA Vaccine Amid Pandemic Concerns
